learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate a knowledge and understanding of the principles of copyright law.
Analyse and interpret the relevant statutory provisions relating to the subject matter of the course.
Identify and apply relevant legal principles to various situations.
Demonstrate skills in legal research, and written and oral communication skills, appropriate to the subject matter of the course.
Critically evaluate the implications and effectiveness of the principles of copyright law.

assessments.task_description:
There will be 7 in class mini quizzes. Each quiz will be conducted online via Blackboard, and will be multiple choice, true/false and the like.


Each quiz will have between 5 and 10 questions relevant to the readings and content of that session. All questions will be of equal weight. Each Quiz will take 5-10 minutes. Your final participation mark will be your overall percentage for all Quizzes.

 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person during class. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) or online search tools will not be permitted in completing this assessment. Any attempted use these tools may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Quizzes to take place in class. You will need to bring a laptop or similar to class, fully charged and with an internet connection.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to choose an essay topic for this course. Students may choose from a list to be provided (preferred) or select their own topic to be approved by the Course Coordinator. Approval for topics not on the list must be sought by Friday 20 March 2026.

 

The following procedure must be followed if seeking approval of your own essay topic from the Course Coordinator:

 

In an email, please state ‘Copyright Law Essay Approval’ in the ‘Subject’ heading. In the body of your email, please simply state ‘My essay topic is’ and then state the question/issue you wish to explore. Please keep your email brief and DO NOT provide any explanation as to why or how you came to choose your essay topic.

 

The Course Coordinator will respond to your email by either approving your essay question/topic, or will let you know if it is not appropriate for this course. You are required to keep a hardcopy of this email correspondence for your own records.

 

Word limit: 1500 words (excluding footnotes). You must clearly state your word count (excluding footnotes) on your Assignment Cover Sheet. You should include a bibliography at the end of your essay.

 

Any material beyond the word limit will not be read. By way of clarification, this word count:

• includes headings;

• does not include text in the header or word count; and

• does not include footnotes but footnotes should be used for citation purposes only. Any substantive content that appears in a footnote will not be read and will not contribute to your mark.

 

For style and referencing, students should refer to the Australian Guide to Legal Citation. See item 3.4 of this course profile for further details.

 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

 

A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

 

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments must be submitted electronically via the submission link on the course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Group Presentation, Written Outline and Reflection
assessments.due_date:
Written outline (10%) 1/05/2026 2:00 pm

Group Presentation (40%)
- Presentations will be in the week commencing 25 May 2026. Week 13,

Reflection (10%) 8/06/2026 2:00 pm
assessments.task_description:
Your final assessment task will be a group presentation. On or before Seminar Weekend Two, you will form a small group (3-5 students).  You may choose your own group members. If you have difficulty forming a group, please contact Ben Gardiner.

Your Group Presentation will be delivered in person. You will have 10 minutes to present plus 5 minutes Q&A with the examining panel.

In the week before the Group Presentation, your group will submit a short Written Outline and, after the Group Presentation, you will submit a short individual Reflection on the group experience.


Question

On 22 April 2026, you will be provided with a multi-part problem question involving various aspects of copyright law.


Written outline

Your group will prepare a short Written Outline (max 500 words) in response to the problem which must be submitted by 1 May 2026, 2:00PM (worth 10%, marked collectively).

More detail about the required format of this outline will be provided in class.


Group presentation

In the week starting 25 May 2026, your group will be assigned a time to present your response to the question in more detailed form. You will have 10 minutes to present plus 5 minutes for questions from the examining panel.

In class, you will be shown how to book a session for your Group Presentation.

Your oral presentation should be consistent with your Written Outline.

Note that each Group Presentation session will be approximately 3 hours, to allow up to 10 to 12 groups to present in that time period.  All group members must be present for the whole session. Your group will be presenting to the course coordinator(s) and (in some cases) a small group of fellow students.

This oral Group Presentation will be worth 40% of your overall mark and will be marked collectively unless there is a compelling reason for different marks to be given to different members of your group.

All group members must contribute to the preparation and presentation of the Written Outline and the Group Presentation.  The oral component of the presentation may be given by a single group member or some/all of the members, however all group members must be present and prepared to answer questions during the Q&A component.  Every group member will receive the same mark, unless a case is made otherwise.  Two assessors will review the presentation (in-person or a recording) to provide moderation of grades.

Resources to support your group work will be provided on the course BlackBoard and discussed in class.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

 

Reflection

After your group presentation, you will submit an INDIVIDUAL reflection on your experiences during this task. This will include reflection on the problem and your answer to it, your experience of presenting it as a group, your contribution to the work, and the group work process. Further guidance will be provided in class.

Your reflection should be no more than 500 words and is worth 10% of your overall mark.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments must be submitted electronically via the submission link on the course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
